description: From Late Latin peripetia, and its source Ancient Greek περιπέτεια (peripéteia), ultimately from περί (perí, “round, around, about”) + the stem of πίπτω (píptō, “to fall”).

entries.meaning: (drama) A sudden reversal of fortune as a plot point in Classical tragedy.
(by extension) Any sudden change in circumstances; a crisis. [from 16th c.]
examples: Once more I was a man in a myth, incapable of understanding it, but somehow aware that understanding it meant it must continue, however sinister its peripeteia.

entries.meaning: (psychoanalysis) A turning point in psychosocial development. [from 1960s]
